facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 190 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 190 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 27, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1172 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 27, 1962 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1172 of 1962.

facts.text: The facts are not in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are number number in dispute.

facts.text: The appellant is a resident of Palwal in Gurgaon District.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a resident of Palwal in Gurgaon District, companymitted house trespass

facts.text: The appellant committed house trespass and tried to outrage the modesty of a girl aged 7 years.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a resident of Palwal in Gurgaon District, companymitted house trespass and tried to outrage the modesty of a girl aged 7 years.

facts.text: The appellant was sent up for trial before the Magistrate, First Class, Palwal.

anchor.surface_text: He was sent up for trial before the Magistrate, First Class, Palwal.

facts.text: The Magistrate convicted the appellant under ss. 451 and 354 of the Indian Penal Code on May 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The said Magistrate, on May 31, 1962, companyvicted him under ss. 451 and 354 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: The Magistrate sentenced the appellant to six months rigorous imprisonment under each count concurrently.

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced him to six months rigorous imprisonment under each companynt and directed that the sentences should run companycurrently.

facts.text: The Magistrate imposed a fine of Rs. 200/- on the appellant under s. 451 IPC and in default two months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: He further imposed a fine of Rs. 200/- on the appellant under s. 451 of the Indian Penal Code and ordered that, in default of payment of fine, he should undergo rigorous imprisonment for two months.

facts.text: The appellant was 16 years old at the time of his conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was 16 years old at the time of his companyviction.

facts.text: The Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 was extended to Gurgaon District on September 1, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was extended to Gurgaon District on September 1, 1962

facts.text: At the time of conviction by the Magistrate, the Act was not in force in Gurgaon District.

anchor.surface_text: and, therefore, at the time the appellant was companyvicted by the Magistrate, the Magistrate had numberpower or duty to make any order under the Act.

facts.text: The appellant preferred an appeal to the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal against his companyviction and sentences to the Additional Sessions Judge, Gurgaon,

facts.text: The Additional Sessions Judge dismissed the appeal on September 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: who by his judgment dated September 22, 1962, dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: By the time the Additional Sessions Judge disposed of the appeal, the Act had come into force.

anchor.surface_text: Though by the time the Additional Sessions Judge disposed of the appeal the said Act had companye into force,

facts.text: Neither the appellant nor the Additional Sessions Judge relied on or exercised powers under the Act in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: neither the appellant relied upon the provisions of the Act number did the learned Additional Sessions Judge exercised his power there- under.

facts.text: The revision filed by the appellant in the High Court was dismissed on September 27, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The revision filed in the High Court by the Appellant was dismissed on September 27, 1962.

facts.text: No ground under s.6 of the Act was taken in the revision petition.

anchor.surface_text: The revision petition was dismissed in limine, but numberground was taken in the revision petition that the Additional Sessions Judge should have acted under s.6 of the Act.

facts.text: After revision dismissal, appellant filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 793 of 1962 requesting High Court to exercise jurisdiction under s.11 of the Act and pass orders under ss.3,4 or 6.

anchor.surface_text: After the revision petition was disposed of, it appears that the appellant filed Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 793 of 1962 requesting the High Court to exercise its jurisdiction under s. 1 of the Act and to pass orders under ss. 3, 4 or 6 thereof.

facts.text: The Criminal Miscellaneous Petition No. 793 of 1962 was dismissed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was also dismissed.

facts.text: The said application is not on the record.

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately the said application is number on the record

facts.text: Appellant filed petition under Art. 134(1)(c) for certificate to appeal to Supreme Court, dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a petition in the High Court under Art. 134 1   c  of the Constitution for a certificate of fitness to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: One ground in Art.134 petition was that High Court should have acted under s.11 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds for seeking such a certificate was that the High Court should have acted under s. 11 of the Act and passed orders under ss. 3, 4 or 6 thereof.

facts.text: Present appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: That petition having been dismissed, the appellant has preferred the present appeal to this Court by obtaining special leave.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 10, 1964 by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: April 10, 1964. The Judgment of Subba Rao and Das Gupta JJ. was delivered by Subba Rao J.

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J. delivered a dissenting opinion.

anchor.surface_text: Raghubar Dayal, J. delivered a dissenting Opinion.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition on September 28, 1962 praying release under ss.3,4,6 of Act or s.562 CrPC.

holdings.text: An appellate court or the High Court in revision can, in exercise of the power conferred under s.11 of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, make an order under s.6(1) thereof even where the trial court convicted before the Act was extended.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore hold that the appellate court in appeal or the High Court in revision can, in exercise of the power conferred under s. 11 of the Act, make an order under s. 6 1  thereof, as the appellate court and the High Court, agreeing with the Magistrate, found the accused guilty of the offences for which he was charged.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.11(1) uses comprehensive phraseology empowering appellate/revisional courts independently; supported by Ramji Missar precedent where appellate court applied s.6 first time; avoids anomalies.

holdings.text: The High Court, acting under s.11 of the Act, can exercise the power conferred on a court under s.6 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the High Court, acting under II of the Act, can exercise the power conferred on a court under s.6 of the Act. It is said that the jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 11 3  of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.11(1) wide and comprehensive, not limited to trial court's powers; expressly includes courts on appeal/revision; beneficial construction for reformative statute.

holdings.text: This Court can direct the High Court to exercise power under s.6(1) of the Act in disposing of an appeal against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether this Court can exercise the same power under s. 11 1  of the Act. This Court in disposing of an appeal against an order of the High Court would be deciding what the High Court should have held

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court's power under Art.136 confined to directing what High Court should have done under s.11(1); must comply with s.6 conditions.

holdings.text: The Probation of Offenders Act, 1958 has retrospective operation as it mollifies the rigour of criminal law without violating Art.20.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, a post facto law and has retrospective operation. In considering the scope of such a provision we must adopt the rule of beneficial construction as enunciated by the modern trend of judicial opinion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Beneficial reformative statute; ex post facto laws reducing punishment valid; modern interpretive trend favors personal liberty.

holdings.text: Courts must interfere under Art.136 where lower courts ignored mandatory provisions of the Act despite late stage.

anchor.surface_text: lastly it is contended that we should not at this very late stage of the proceeding, and especially in view of the observations of the Additional Sessions Judge in sentencing the accused, interfere with the order of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory duty of courts to apply Act to under-21 offenders regardless of plea; recent extension overlooked; public interest in reform.

holdings.text: Under s.6(1) & (2), court shall not sentence under-21 offender to imprisonment without calling probation officer report as condition precedent.

anchor.surface_text: A court cannot impose a sentence of imprisonment on a person under 21 years of age found guilty... unless... call for a report from the probation officer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory language 'shall call for a report'; 'if any' covers non-submission, not option to skip.

holdings.text: Appellate court cannot make order under the Act if trial court could not on date of conviction due to Act not in force; no retrospective effect implied.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No express or implied retrospective provision; s.11(1) limited to cases where trial court could act; avoids reopening pre-Act convictions; textual reading.

holdings.text: s.6 applies only to court finding guilty for first time; appellate confirming conviction does not 'find guilty' anew.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that action under these sections can be taken by the Court which finds a person guilty of the offence for the first time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'court by which the person is found guilty'; s.11(1) 'also' indicates secondary to trial court power.

precedents.citation: Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar 1

anchor.surface_text: This view gets support from the judgment of this Court in Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar 1 . The facts of that case relevant to the present case were as follows The Assistant Sessions Judge, Arrah, companymitted one Basist under s. 307 and s. 326 of the Indian Penal Code. As the offences under the said sections were punishable with imprisonment for life, the provisions of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, were number applicable to Basist and, therefore, the Assistant Sessions Judge sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 6 years under s. 307 of the Indian Penal Code and for 4 years rigorous imprisonment under s. 326 of the said Code and ordered the sentences to run companycurrently. But the High Court on appeal found Basist guilty of an offence under s.324 of the Indian Penal Code. It was companytended that the High Court companyld number make an order under s.6 1  of the Probation of Offenders Act, 1958, on the ground that s. 11 of the Act did number companyfer such a power on the High Court. Dealing with this argument, this Court observed- It is however possible that the words in s. 11 1  pass an order under the Act are number to be companystrued so strictly and literally, but to be understood to mean to exercise the powers or jurisdiction companyferred by the Act. This wide interpretation might perhaps be justified by the scope and object of this section. Section 11 is to apply numberwithstanding anything in the Code or any other law to all companyrts empowered to sentence offenders to imprisonment. To read a beneficial provision of this universal type in a restricted sense, so as to companyfine the power of these companyrts to the exercise of the powers under ss. 3 and 4 alone would number, in our opinion, be in accord with sound principles of statutory interpretation. We are therefore inclined to hold that the Courts mentioned in s. II be they trial companyrts or exercising appellate or revisional jurisdiction are thereby empowered to exercise the jurisdiction companyferred on Courts number only under ss. 3 and 4 and the companysequential provisions but also under s.6. 1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 745, 755.

precedents.case_name: Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: an appellate court or a revisional court can make an order under s.6(1) of the Act in exercise of its power under s.11(1) thereof even for the first time even though the trial court could not have made such an order
precedents.cited_holding: the Courts mentioned in s. 11 be they trial courts or exercising appellate or revisional jurisdiction are thereby empowered to exercise the jurisdiction conferred on Courts not only under ss. 3 and 4 and consequential provisions but also under s.6

anchor.surface_text: statutory interpretation. We are therefore inclined to hold that the Courts mentioned in s. II be they trial companyrts or exercising appellate or revisional jurisdiction are thereby empowered to exercise the jurisdiction companyferred on Courts number only under ss. 3 and 4 and the companysequential provisions but also under s.6.1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 745, 755. When it was companytended that the word may in s. 11 of the Act empowers the appellate companyrt or the High Court to exercise the power at its option and the words any order under the Act empower it to make an order without reference to the standards laid down in the Act, this Court rejected both the companytentions.

precedents.case_name: Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: wide interpretation of s.11(1) to empower appellate and revisional courts to pass orders under the Act including s.6

anchor.surface_text: The Code does number provide for the payment of companyts and provides for the payment of companypensation when ordered out of the fine imposed on an accused vide ss. 545 and 546A of the Code. This Court companysidered certain provisions of the Act in Ramji Missar v. State of Bihar 1  and held that the crucial date for the application of the aforesaid sections viz., ss. 3, 4 and 6 of the Act to, the case of an accused whose companyviction by the trial Court of offences to which those sections do number apply, was altered by the appellate Court to an offence to which the provisions of those sections applied, would be the  late of the decision of the trial Court in view of the terms of the section on grounds of logic as well as on the theory that the order passed by an appellate Court was the companyrect order which the trial Court should have passed. This tends to support the view I have expressed above.
